cytopy.flow.utilities¶

Functions

An implementation of faithful downsampling as described in: Zare H, Shooshtari P, Gupta A, Brinkman R.

Hellinger distance between two discrete distributions.

Calculate the Jensen-Shannon Divergence between two PDFs

Estimate best bandwidth for KDE using cross validation

Perform Kernel Density Estimation for a multivariant data.

Standard function for loading data from an experiment, transforming, scaling, and sampling.

ordered_load_transform(sample_id, …)

Wrapper function for load_and_transform that adds convenience for multi-processing (data can be ordered post-hoc); returns a tuple, first element is the subject ID and the second element the population dataframe.
cytopy.flow.utilities.faithful_downsampling(data: numpy.array, h: float)¶

An implementation of faithful downsampling as described in: Zare H, Shooshtari P, Gupta A, Brinkman R. Data reduction for spectral clustering to analyze high throughput flow cytometry data. BMC Bioinformatics 2010;11:403

Parameters

  • data (Numpy.array) – numpy array to be down-sampled

  • h (float) – radius for nearest neighbours search

Returns

Down-sampled array

Return type

Numpy.array

cytopy.flow.utilities.hellinger_dot(p: numpy.array, q: numpy.array) → float¶

Hellinger distance between two discrete distributions. Original code found here: https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/gist/Teagum/460a508cda99f9874e4ff828e1896862

Parameters

  • p (Numpy.array) – discrete probability distribution, p

  • q (Numpy.array) – discrete probability distribution, q

Returns

Hellinger Distance

Return type

Numpy.float

cytopy.flow.utilities.jsd_divergence(p: numpy.array, q: numpy.array) → float¶

Calculate the Jensen-Shannon Divergence between two PDFs

Parameters

  • p (Numpy.array) – discrete probability distribution, p

  • q (Numpy.array) – discrete probability distribution, q

Returns

Jenson-Shannon Divergence

Return type

Numpy.float

cytopy.flow.utilities.kde_bandwidth_cv(x, bandwidth_search: tuple = None, cv: int = 20)¶

Estimate best bandwidth for KDE using cross validation

Parameters

  • x – data for KDE

  • bandwidth_search (tuple, optional) – tuple specifying range of bandwidth values to search (start, end) in cross validation; if value is None, 5th and 95th quartile of data is used for lower ad upper limit respectively

  • cv (int, (default=20)) – number of folds to use in cross validation (default = 20)

Returns

Optimal bandwidth

Return type

float

cytopy.flow.utilities.kde_multivariant(x: numpy.array, bandwidth: str = 'cross_val', bandwidth_search: tuple = None, bins: int = 1000, **kwargs) → numpy.array¶

Perform Kernel Density Estimation for a multivariant data. Function is a wrapper for methods provided by the scikit-learn library. See scikit-learn documentation for available kernels (default = gaussian). Cross-validation available for bandwidth search by setting bandwidth argument to ‘cross_val’ otherwise a float value is expected.

Parameters

  • x (Numpy.array) – data to perform KDE upon; if 1 dimensional data must be reshaped e.g. np.array.reshape(-1, 1)

  • bandwidth (str or float, (default='cross_val')) – either float value for bandwidth or ‘cross-val’ to estimate bandwidth using cross-validation

  • bandwidth_search (tuple, optional) – tuple specifying range of bandwidth values to search (start, end) in cross validaiton; ignored if bandwidth != ‘cross_val’

  • bins (int, (default=1000)) – bin size for generating grid of sample locations for scoring probability estimate

  • kwargs – additional keyword arguments to pass to sklearn.neighbors.KernelDensity

Returns

Probability density estimate

Return type

Numpy.array

cytopy.flow.utilities.load_and_transform(sample_id: str, experiment: cytopy.data.fcs_experiments.FCSExperiment, root_population: str, transform: str, scale: str = None, sample_n: int = None) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame¶

Standard function for loading data from an experiment, transforming, scaling, and sampling. experiment: Experiment object that sample belongs to

Parameters

  • sample_id (str) – ID for sample to load

  • experiment (FCSExperiment) – Experiment of interest

  • root_population (str) – name of root population to load from sample

  • transform (str, optional) – name of transformation method to apply (if None, data is returned untransformed)

  • scale (str, optional) – name of scalling method to apply after transformation (if None, no scaling is applied)

  • sample_n (int, optional) – number of events to return (sample is uniform; if None, no sampling occurs)

Returns

Return type

Population DataFrame or None

cytopy.flow.utilities.ordered_load_transform(sample_id: str, experiment: cytopy.data.fcs_experiments.FCSExperiment, root_population: str, transform: str, scale: str = None, sample_n: int = None) -> (<class 'str'>, <class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>)¶

Wrapper function for load_and_transform that adds convenience for multi-processing (data can be ordered post-hoc); returns a tuple, first element is the subject ID and the second element the population dataframe.

Parameters

  • experiment (FCSExperiment) – Experiment object that sample belongs to

  • sample_id (str) – ID for sample to load

  • root_population (str) – name of root population to load from sample

  • transform (str) – name of transformation method to apply (if None, data is returned untransformed)

  • scale (str, optional) – name of scalling method to apply after transformation (if None, no scaling is applied)

  • sample_n (int, optional) – number of events to return (sample is uniform; if None, no sampling occurs)

Returns

sample_id, population DataFrame

Return type

str, Pandas.DataFrame or None
